_prev_prog_3.Description:
Process Safety Information (PSI) is physical, chemical, and toxicological information related to the chemicals,  process,  and  equipment  that  are  in  regular  use  at  the  CWI  facility. It  is  used  to document the configuration of a process, its characteristics, its limitations, and as data for process hazard analyses. CWI maintains current safety information regarding its chemicals storage in accordance with 40 CFR 68.65 as well as Safety Data Sheets (SDS).



The purpose of this PSI is to:

     -Ensure understanding of safety-related aspects of equipment, processes, and chemicals.

     -Know the limits those aspects place on operations.

     -Adopt accepted standards and codes where applicable.

     -Having updated safety information about the process is the foundation of an effective prevention program.



CITCO WATER, INC. - RMP

     -Most  elements,  including hazard  review/process  hazard  analysis, depend on accuracy  and thoroughness of information required by this element.

     -Ensure Up-to-date safety information (Hazardous/regulated substances)

     -Ensure SDS information is current and from actual chemical supplier

     -Understand Maximum intended inventories

     -Understand safe upper and lower limits for temperatures, pressures, flows, composition

     -Understand specifications codes/standards used to design, build, and operate

     -Ensure compliance with good engineering practices

     -Update when major change makes information inaccurate

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
It is the policy of Citco Water, Inc. (CWI) Huntington, West Virginia facility management to implement the requirements of this Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68 Risk Management Program Level 3. The objective is to minimize the risk of a release 

of a hazardous material and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to CWI employees, the public and  the  environment.  This  objective  will  be  accomplished  by  utilizing  best  management  practices, providing appropriate training to all employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the  local  emergency  response  providers.  CWI  management  is  committed  to  providing  the  resources necessary to implement this policy.



The Huntington, WV facility is governed by a set of USEPA regulations that require planning and facility activities  intended to  prevent  a release of  hazardous material, or  if a release  inadvertently  occurs, to minimize  the  consequences  of  a  release  to  the  employees  of  the  facility,  the  public  and  to  the environment. These regulations include: 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention 40 CFR Part 302, Emergency  Planning  and  Community  Right-to-Know  

Act  (EPCRA)  The  key  concepts  in  CWI  release prevention program are employee participation, appropriate maintenance of equipment, and appropriate training of all employees. Employee participation in the release prevention program is encouraged and supported  by  CWI  management.  Key  personnel  are  responsible  for  conducting  and  implementing  the findings from the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage. CWI is committed to  providing  

appropriate  training  to  all  employees  regarding  safety  procedures.  New  employees  are provided comprehensive safety training during their initial orientation for the facility. In addition,  CWI conducts regularly scheduled safety training for a

ll employees each year.



Location and Background

CWI operates an industrial supply distribution center at this location. Chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders are received, stored, and shipped to public and private water and wastewater treatment facilities. Two chemicals, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide are stored at the facility in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68. The facility stores 150-pound and 2,000-pound cylinders of chlorine, and 150-pound and 2,000-pound cylinders of sulfur dioxide. Chlorine and sulfur dioxide detection systems are present at the facility.





Five-Year Release History

No incidents to report.





Emergency Response Program

Certain abnormal situations require rapid and correct response to limit the potential for personnel injury, damage to plant equipment or the environment. The emergency response program is intended to provide a description of necessary responses and assigned duties for designated personnel to minimize effects of the emergency incident. This response plan is specific to a chemical release, which would have the potential to cause risk to the public or the environment.
